message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s inability to completely void and fullness in the suprapubic region, along with a bladder scan showing 450cc, suggest urinary retention. The next appropriate step in management is catheterization. Oral bethanechol chloride is used to treat urinary retention caused by poor bladder muscle function. Intravenous neostigmine methylsulfate is used for the same purpose, but it also carries potential side effects. Intravenous furosemide is used to treat fluid overload and has no role in treating urinary retention.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and bladder scan results indicate urinary retention, which requires catheterization to relieve the obstruction. Oral bethanechol chloride and intravenous neostigmine methylsulfate are used to treat urinary retention in some situations, but catheterization is the first step in management. Intravenous furosemide is not indicated as it is a diuretic used to remove excess fluid from the body.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s inability to completely void and the fullness and tenderness in the suprapubic region suggest urinary retention. The bladder scan result of 450cc confirms this. Catheterization is the next appropriate step to relieve the retention and prevent further complications. Option A and B are medications used to treat urinary retention but are not appropriate in this situation. Option C is a diuretic and will not help with urinary retention.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest urinary retention, and the bladder scan confirms it. The next appropriate step is catheterization to relieve the bladder distension and prevent further complications. Oral bethanechol chloride and intravenous neostigmine methylsulfate are medications used to stimulate bladder contractions and would not be appropriate in this situation. Intravenous furosemide is a diuretic and would not help with urinary retention.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest urinary retention, which is confirmed by the bladder scan. The next appropriate step in management would be catheterization to relieve the urinary retention. Options A and B are medications used to treat urinary retention caused by bladder atony, which is not the case here. Option C is a diuretic that would not help with urinary retention.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s inability to completely void and fullness in the suprapubic region indicate urinary retention. The bladder scan confirms a significant amount of urine in the bladder. The next appropriate step in management would be catheterization to relieve the urinary retention. Oral bethanechol chloride and intravenous neostigmine methylsulfate are used in cases of bladder atony, while intravenous furosemide is used for fluid overload or congestive heart failure.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has urinary retention with a large postvoid residual, which can lead to complications such as urinary tract infection, bladder damage, and hydronephrosis. Therefore, the next appropriate step is to relieve the urinary retention via catheterization. Options (A) and (B) are medications used to enhance bladder emptying, but they may not be effective in a case of urinary retention. Option (C) is a diuretic and will not help with urinary retention.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is experiencing urinary retention with a high bladder volume, and the most appropriate next step is to perform catheterization. Options A and B are medications used for urinary retention without significant bladder distension, while option C is a diuretic and not indicated in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is experiencing urinary retention, with a full bladder of 450cc, and catheterization is the appropriate next step in management to relieve the obstruction. Bethanechol chloride and neostigmine methylsulfate are medications used to treat urinary retention, but immediate catheterization is recommended in this scenario to prevent further complications. Furosemide is a diuretic and not indicated for this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has postoperative urinary retention with a high urine volume. The next appropriate step in management is catheterization to relieve the urine accumulation and prevent further complications. Options A and B are medications used to treat urinary retention but catheterization is more appropriate in this situation. Option C is a diuretic and not appropriate in this situation.
